justification: Participants completed the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS); the authors note that this questionnaire was used to assess participants’ mood states, i.e., levels of positive affect.
The PANAS contains both positive and negative affect items, and the paper explicitly says it was administered to measure participants’ mood states, which include negative affect.
The methods list the Beck's Hopelessness Scale (BHS) and explain that it captures ‘their tendency to develop hopelessness under challenging situations.’

measured_by: Behavioral Inhibition System/Behavioral Activation System (BIS/BAS) Scale
justification: The BIS/BAS Scale was administered to assess personality traits related to Pavlovian-type response tendencies; the BIS component indexes behavioral inhibition.

measured_by: Behavioral Inhibition System/Behavioral Activation System (BIS/BAS) Scale
justification: The same BIS/BAS instrument also measures Behavioral Activation System traits, reflecting individuals’ activation/approach tendencies.
The LCB Scale is listed among the questionnaires and is described as assessing ‘the attribution of controllability to internal or external sources,’ i.e., locus of control.
The Need for Cognition scale was given to measure ‘the predisposition to implement cognitive effort in demanding tasks,’ i.e., the construct of need for cognition.
After each task block participants rated ‘the degree to which you felt you could control the outcomes’ on a 0–100 visual analogue scale, indicating that controllability was measured via VAS.
Participants also rated ‘how successful you think you were in collecting points!’ on the same 0–100 VAS, making the VAS the measurement instrument for perceived success.
Mean and peak pain in each block were measured with VAS questions (‘Please rate the maximum pain level you felt in this block!’), showing that pain intensity was recorded with a VAS.
The authors state that ‘Pavlovian bias … was done via calculating the Pavlovian Performance Index (PPI),’ indicating that the PPI serves as the measure of Pavlovian bias.

measured_by: Method of limits using thermode-delivered heat stimulation
justification: Pain tolerance was determined with ‘8 runs of gradually increasing heat stimulation ("method of limits", from 32 to 50 °C…)’ and the average termination temperature was taken as the tolerance measure.
